results.justification: The paper explicitly states the methodology, focusing on implementing and evaluating Differential Privacy (DP) in Learning Analytics (LA). "Our contributions are as follows...Introduction of the first DP framework for education and learning analytics..."
The DEFLA framework is presented as a step-by-step process. "Below, we introduce each step of DEFLA." and subsequent paragraphs detail each step.
The paper states the dataset used: "We demonstrate DEFLA through a LA experiment using the popular dataset from the Open University (OULAD) [28]." and provides a citation for the dataset.

The paper provides some description of the dataset, including its origin and contents: "This dataset also contains various personal details about students, such as age and residence...This dataset is anonymized..."
The paper does not detail the original data collection methods for the OULAD dataset; it only describes the dataset as it is used in the study.
The paper does not mention whether the analysis code is publicly available.
Since the code is not shared, there is no information about scripts for data cleaning, analysis, and visualization.

The paper uses quantitative methods, including statistical analysis of Utility Loss, Privacy Leakage, and True Revealed Records. Metrics and their calculations are described. "We adopt three effective metrics for analysing the performance of DP...Utility Loss, Privacy Leakage, and True Revealed Records."
The analysis is primarily quantitative; there is no mention of qualitative data or analysis.
The paper does not mention or link to any preregistration.
The paper presents the results of the experiment, including figures illustrating Utility Loss, Privacy Leakage, and True Revealed Records. "Figure 3 depicts Utility Loss..."
The paper discusses limitations, including computational demands and challenges with small datasets. "The limitation of this paper is as follows...DP also struggles with small datasets..."
